title: Complex Numbers
description: The complex numbers and their geometric interpretation.
markdownContent:
ðŸ“˜ Complex Numbers

1. Definition and Basics

Complex numbers extend the real numbers by introducing an imaginary unit i with the property $i^2 = -1$.

Representation

A complex number z has the form:

$$z = a + bi$$

with $a,b \in \mathbb{R}$, where:

  • a: Real part Re(z)
  • b: Imaginary part Im(z)

2. Operations

Addition

$$(a + bi) + (c + di) = (a + c) + (b + d)i$$

Multiplication

$$(a + bi)(c + di) = (ac - bd) + (ad + bc)i$$

Conjugation

$$\overline{a + bi} = a - bi$$

Modulus

$$|a + bi| = \sqrt{a^2 + b^2}$$

3. Geometric Interpretation

Complex Plane

Complex numbers can be represented as points in the plane:

  • x-axis: Real part
  • y-axis: Imaginary part

Polar Form

$$z = r(\cos \varphi + i\sin \varphi) = re^{i\varphi}$$

where:

  • r = |z|: Modulus
  • Ï†: Argument (angle to the positive real axis)

4. Important Formulas

Euler's Formula

$$e^{i\varphi} = \cos \varphi + i\sin \varphi$$

De Moivre's Formula

$$(r(\cos \varphi + i\sin \varphi))^n = r^n(\cos(n\varphi) + i\sin(n\varphi))$$

Roots

The nth roots of a complex number z = $re^{i\varphi}$ are:

$$\sqrt[n]{z}_k = \sqrt[n]{r} \cdot e^{i(\frac{\varphi + 2\pi k}{n})}$$

for k = 0,1,...,n-1

5. Properties

Algebraic Closure

Every non-constant polynomial with complex coefficients has a complex root.

Fundamental Theorem of Algebra

A polynomial of degree n has exactly n complex roots, counting multiplicities.

Field Properties

$\mathbb{C}$ is an algebraically closed field of characteristic 0.

6. Applications

Electrical Engineering

  • AC circuit analysis
  • Impedance analysis
  • Frequency analysis

Quantum Mechanics

  • Wave functions
  • SchrÃ¶dinger equation
  • Quantum states

Fractals

  • Mandelbrot set
  • Julia sets
  • Iterated function systems
